claim: Chameleons change colors to regulate their temperature.

supporting.text: Chameleons have specialized cells called chromatophores that expand or contract to reflect or absorb sunlight, aiding in thermoregulation.

attacks.text: Chameleons have specialized cells called chromatophores that expand or contract to reflect or absorb sunlight, aiding in thermoregulation.
While chromatophores exist, studies show their primary function is camouflage and communication, not thermoregulation.
Thermoregulation is still observed in chameleons, and chromatophore activity correlates with temperature changes in controlled experiments.
Other reptiles without chromatophores (like snakes) regulate temperature more efficiently, suggesting chromatophores are not the main thermoregulatory mechanism.
Chameleons inhabit environments where both camouflage and thermoregulation are critical, allowing chromatophores to serve dual purposes.

supporting.text: Darker colors absorb more heat, which helps chameleons warm up in cooler environments, while lighter colors reflect heat to cool down.

attacks.text: Darker colors absorb more heat, which helps chameleons warm up in cooler environments, while lighter colors reflect heat to cool down.
Studies show chameleons primarily change colors for communication and camouflage, not temperature regulation.
While communication is primary, some species do exhibit temperature-linked color shifts in controlled experiments.
Infrared imaging reveals negligible body temperature changes during most color shifts in wild chameleons.
The surface area for heat exchange through skin color is too small to significantly impact core body temperature.

supporting.text: Scientific studies have observed chameleons changing to darker hues in cooler temperatures and lighter hues in warmer temperatures, supporting the thermoregulation hypothesis.

attacks.text: Scientific studies have observed chameleons changing to darker hues in cooler temperatures and lighter hues in warmer temperatures, supporting the thermoregulation hypothesis.
Chameleons primarily change color for communication and camouflage, with temperature regulation being a secondary or coincidental effect.
Studies show chameleons change color in response to social signals even in temperature-controlled environments, indicating communication is the primary driver.
The observed color changes could be explained by humidity or light exposure rather than direct temperature regulation.
Controlled experiments show chameleon color changes correlate more strongly with temperature than humidity when isolated variables are tested.

supporting.text: The ability to change color for temperature regulation is an evolutionary advantage, allowing chameleons to maintain optimal body temperatures in varying climates.

attacks.text: The ability to change color for temperature regulation is an evolutionary advantage, allowing chameleons to maintain optimal body temperatures in varying climates.
Research shows that chameleons primarily change colors for communication and camouflage, not temperature regulation.
While communication is a primary function, some studies suggest color changes may secondarily affect temperature absorption.
Many reptiles without color-changing abilities thermoregulate effectively through behavioral adaptations, questioning the necessity of this trait for temperature control.
The energy cost of rapid color change would likely outweigh any thermoregulatory benefits in most environments.

supporting.text: Infrared imaging studies have shown that chameleons with darker skin exhibit higher surface temperatures, confirming the role of color change in heat absorption.

attacks.text: Infrared imaging studies have shown that chameleons with darker skin exhibit higher surface temperatures, confirming the role of color change in heat absorption.
While darker skin may absorb more heat, studies have shown that chameleons primarily change color for communication and camouflage, not temperature regulation.
The infrared imaging studies cited in A5 were conducted in controlled lab environments, which may not accurately reflect natural behavior in the wild.
Even if temperature regulation is a secondary function, it does not negate the primary role of color change in social signaling and predator avoidance.
Some species of chameleons exhibit color changes in response to temperature fluctuations in their natural habitats, supporting the dual-purpose theory.
